newsitem.title: USA: FAA orders flap inspection for Boeing 767s.
newsitem.headline: FAA orders flap inspection for Boeing 767s.

text.p: U.S. safety officials on Wednesday issued an emergency order to inspect the wing flap bolts on some Boeing Co. 767s after a bolt failed last week and a Delta Air Lines Inc. jet lost a 20-foot (6-metre) flap section.

In the March 27 incident, the flap fell off as the Delta plane was approaching the Dallas airport. No one was injured on the ground and the plane landed safety. The incident is being investigated by the National Transportation Safety Board.
The Federal Aviation Administration said the order requires operators of older 767s to inspect the bolt within the next 15 days for cracking, replacing them if needed.

FAA acting administrator Barry Valentine said that "Although this recent incident is still under investigation, we are taking this precautionary measure to ensure that we continue to provide the highest level of safety to the traveling public."

The inspections are mandatory for 767s that have flown at least 25,000 hours or 10,000 flights. There are about 210 of the planes flying worldwide, including 107 in the U.S. registered fleet affected by the order.
It said the cost would be about $420 per plane.

The FAA said that affected U.S. carriers, in addition to Delta, were American Airlines, a unit of AMR Corp ., United Airlines, a unit of UAL Corp., Alaska Airlines and United Parcel Service of America Inc..
